{{Geobox|Protected Area | name = Moore State Park | other_name = | category = [[Massachusetts]] State Park | image = Moore State Park Sawmill.jpg | image_caption = Sawmill at Moore State Park | image_size = 200px | free = 730 acres (3.0 km2) | free_type = Area | location = [[Paxton, Massachusetts]] | elevation = | prominence = | lat_d = | lat_m = | lat_s = | lat_NS = | long_d = | long_m = | long_s = | long_EW = | length = | length_orientation = | width = | width_orientation = | area = | geology = | biome = [[Oak-hickory forest]],
[[northern hardwood forest]], pond, wetlands | plant = [[Quercus rubra|Red Oak]], [[Eastern White Pine]] | animal = | established = | management = [[Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation]] | map = | map_caption = | map_background = | map_locator = | map_locator_x = | map_locator_y = | website = [http://www.mass.gov/dcr/parks/central/more.htm Moore State Park] | footnotes = }} '''Moore State Park''' is a {{convert|730|acre|km2|sing=on}} [[state park]] located in [[Paxton, Massachusetts]]. The park is managed by the [[Department of Conservation and Recreation (Massachusetts)|Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation]]. Features of the park include a numerous historical sites (principally foundations), a restored [[sawmill]], two-thirds of [[Eames Pond]], waterfalls and mill chutes, and abundant [[azaleas]], [[rhododendrons]], and [[Kalmia latifolia|mountain laurel]]. Park recreational opportunities include canoeing, fishing, hiking, cross country skiing, and picnicing. Interpretive programs and concerts are held in season. Moore State Park is located off [[Massachusetts Route 31]]. ==History== [[Image:Kalmia latifolia1.jpg|thumb|left|Mountain Laurel]] A portion of the land within Moore State Park was once the home to at least five 18th and 19th century [[watermill]]s that were powered by the cascading waters of Turkey Hill Brook that fall 90 feet over a 400-foot run. The first mills built on the site were a [[gristmill]] and [[sawmill]] as early as 1747. The remnants of this mill village are still visible and include, in addition to the mills, a [[triphammer]], [[quarry]], [[School|school house]], and [[tavern]]. In the early 20th-century, the property became a private [[Estate (house)|estate]]; large portions of it have subsequently been included in the state park. ==References== *[http://www.mass.gov/dcr/parks/central/more.htm Moore State Park] *[http://www.mass.gov/dcr/parks/trails/Moore.gif Moore State Park trail map] {{Protected Areas of Massachusetts}} {{coord|42|19|05.56|N|71|57|25.86|W|display=title}} [[Category:Massachusetts state parks]] [[Category:Parks in Worcester County, Massachusetts]] {{Massachusetts-geo-stub}}
